trans-unit.source: .NET Assembly File Format
trans-unit.target: .NET Assembly File Format

trans-unit.source: .NET Assembly File Format
trans-unit.target: .NET Assembly File Format

trans-unit.source: .NET, .NET Core
trans-unit.target: .NET, .NET Core

trans-unit.source: .NET Assembly File Format
trans-unit.target: .NET Assembly File Format

trans-unit.source: The .NET platform defines a binary file format - “assembly” - that is used to fully-describe and contain .NET programs.
trans-unit.target: The .NET platform defines a binary file format - “assembly” - that is used to fully-describe and contain .NET programs.

trans-unit.source: Assemblies are used for the programs themselves as well as any dependent libraries.
trans-unit.target: Assemblies are used for the programs themselves as well as any dependent libraries.

trans-unit.source: A .NET program can be executed as one of more assemblies, with no other required artifacts, beyond the appropriate .NET runtime.
trans-unit.target: A .NET program can be executed as one of more assemblies, with no other required artifacts, beyond the appropriate .NET runtime.

trans-unit.source: Native dependencies, including operating system APIs, are a separate concern and are not contained within the .NET assembly format, although are sometimes described with this format (for example, WinRT).
trans-unit.target: Native dependencies, including operating system APIs, are a separate concern and are not contained within the .NET assembly format, although are sometimes described with this format (for example, WinRT).

trans-unit.source: Each CLI component carries the metadata for declarations, implementations, and references specific to that component.
trans-unit.target: Each CLI component carries the metadata for declarations, implementations, and references specific to that component.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, the component-specific metadata is referred to as component metadata, and the resulting component is said to be self-describing – from ECMA 335 I.9.1, Components and assemblies.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, the component-specific metadata is referred to as component metadata, and the resulting component is said to be self-describing – from ECMA 335 I.9.1, Components and assemblies.

trans-unit.source: The format is fully specified and standardized as ECMA 335.
trans-unit.target: The format is fully specified and standardized as ECMA 335.

trans-unit.source: All .NET compilers and runtimes use this format.
trans-unit.target: All .NET compilers and runtimes use this format.

trans-unit.source: The presence of a documented and infrequently updated binary format has been a major benefit (arguably a requirement) for interoperatibility.
trans-unit.target: The presence of a documented and infrequently updated binary format has been a major benefit (arguably a requirement) for interoperatibility.

trans-unit.source: The format was last updated in a substantive way in 2005 (.NET 2.0) to accommodate generics and processor architecture.
trans-unit.target: The format was last updated in a substantive way in 2005 (.NET 2.0) to accommodate generics and processor architecture.

trans-unit.source: The format is CPU- and OS-agnostic.
trans-unit.target: The format is CPU- and OS-agnostic.

trans-unit.source: It has been used as part of .NET runtimes that target many chips and CPUs.
trans-unit.target: It has been used as part of .NET runtimes that target many chips and CPUs.

trans-unit.source: While the format itself has Windows heritage, it is implementable on any operating system.
trans-unit.target: While the format itself has Windows heritage, it is implementable on any operating system.

trans-unit.source: It’s arguably most significant choice for OS interoperability is that most values are stored in little-endian format.
trans-unit.target: It’s arguably most significant choice for OS interoperability is that most values are stored in little-endian format.

trans-unit.source: It doesn’t have a specific affinity to machine pointer size (for example, 32-bit, 64-bit).
trans-unit.target: It doesn’t have a specific affinity to machine pointer size (for example, 32-bit, 64-bit).

trans-unit.source: The .NET assembly format is also very descriptive about the structure of a given program or library.
trans-unit.target: The .NET assembly format is also very descriptive about the structure of a given program or library.

trans-unit.source: It describes the internal components of an assembly, specifically: assembly references and types defined and their internal structure.
trans-unit.target: It describes the internal components of an assembly, specifically: assembly references and types defined and their internal structure.

trans-unit.source: Tools or APIs can read and process this information for display or to make programmatic decisions.
trans-unit.target: Tools or APIs can read and process this information for display or to make programmatic decisions.

trans-unit.source: Format
trans-unit.target: Format

trans-unit.source: The .NET binary format is based on the Windows [PE file](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portable_Executable) format.
trans-unit.target: The .NET binary format is based on the Windows [PE file](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portable_Executable) format.

trans-unit.source: In fact, .NET class libraries are conformant Windows PEs, and appear on first glance to be Windows dynamic link libraries (DLLs) or application executables (EXEs).
trans-unit.target: In fact, .NET class libraries are conformant Windows PEs, and appear on first glance to be Windows dynamic link libraries (DLLs) or application executables (EXEs).

trans-unit.source: This is a very useful characteristic on Windows, where they can masquerade as native executable binaries and get some of the same treatment (for example, OS load, PE tools).
trans-unit.target: This is a very useful characteristic on Windows, where they can masquerade as native executable binaries and get some of the same treatment (for example, OS load, PE tools).

trans-unit.source: Assembly headers
trans-unit.target: Assembly headers

trans-unit.source: Assembly Headers Assemblies headers from ECMA 335 II.25.1, Structure of the runtime file format.
trans-unit.target: Assembly Headers Assemblies headers from ECMA 335 II.25.1, Structure of the runtime file format.

trans-unit.source: Processing the Assemblies
trans-unit.target: Processing the Assemblies

trans-unit.source: It is possible to write tools or APIs to process assemblies.
trans-unit.target: It is possible to write tools or APIs to process assemblies.

trans-unit.source: Assembly information enables making programmatic decisions at runtime, re-writing assemblies, providing API IntelliSense in an editor and generating documentation.
trans-unit.target: Assembly information enables making programmatic decisions at runtime, re-writing assemblies, providing API IntelliSense in an editor and generating documentation.

trans-unit.source: [System.Reflection](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.reflection.aspx) and [Mono.Cecil](http://www.mono-project.com/docs/tools+libraries/libraries/Mono.Cecil/) are good examples of tools that are frequently used for this purpose.
trans-unit.target: [System.Reflection](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.reflection.aspx) and [Mono.Cecil](http://www.mono-project.com/docs/tools+libraries/libraries/Mono.Cecil/) are good examples of tools that are frequently used for this purpose.
